channel.title: I would like working doors for a blank client
channel.description: Title says it all, can anyone teach me how to add working doors? don't say doors.cfg i aready know that shit, it's a blank server and client it doesn't have shit added to it. So how do i make doors FROM SCRATCH. But i seriously need a source with doors!

item.title: I would like working doors for a blank client
item.dc:creator: @pure2ownage Pure_
item.description:
@pure2ownage wrote:

[quote=“DAn0194, post:26, topic:539690”][quote author=HcoJustin link=topic=658532.msg4405218#msg4405218 date=1391738543]
The stupidity from Dan is unreal. Pls go with an implementation similar to Pure_ when doing this.
[/quote]
I re-read some of my comments and I do think I took it overboard with his system(was mad that day). His system isn’t actually bad. Not everyone has that Position class but overall I think that it is pretty good what he is doing as he doesn’t have to loop through each door he has to open like mine was doing.[/quote]Formatting the position class shouldn’t be hard, long as you read and write it using the same format.

[hr]

Just to clarify you need to call DoorHandler.loadDoors(file path) on start-up somewhere. This doesn’t support multiple doors but it would be a small amendment.

Example config file:

[code]# object faces go 0, -1, -2, -3 west, north, east, south or something, figure it out lol!

the following isnt a real door btw

OBJECT ID POSITION DEFAULT_STATE(OPEN?) OPEN_FACE CLOSE_FACE

1320 X Y Z FALSE -2 -3[/code]

You wanted the send object packet, here’s its structure.

[code=java] public void sendObject(int objectId, int objectType, int objectFace,
Position pos) {
// Sending obj coords
StreamBuffer.OutBuffer out = StreamBuffer.newOutBuffer(16);
out.writeHeader(getEncryptor(), 85);
out.writeByte(pos.getLocalY(player.getPosition()), StreamBuffer.ValueType.C);
out.writeByte(pos.getLocalX(player.getPosition()), StreamBuffer.ValueType.C);

    // Removing current object
    out.writeHeader(getEncryptor(), 101);
    out.writeByte((objectType << 2) + (objectFace & 3), StreamBuffer.ValueType.C);
    out.writeByte(0);
    
    // Sending new object
    if (objectId != -1) {
        out.writeHeader(getEncryptor(), 151);
        out.writeByte(0, StreamBuffer.ValueType.A);
        out.writeShort(objectId, StreamBuffer.ByteOrder.LITTLE);
        out.writeByte((objectType << 2) + (objectFace & 3), StreamBuffer.ValueType.S);
    }
    send(out.getBuffer());
}[/code]

Read full topic
item.source: I would like working doors for a blank client

Not everyone has that Position class but overall I think that it is pretty good what he is doing as he doesn’t have to loop through each door he has to open like mine was doing.

item.title: I would like working doors for a blank client
item.dc:creator: @Dan0194 Dan0194
item.description:
@Dan0194 wrote:

[quote=“Pure_, post:19, topic:539690”][quote author=DAn0194 link=topic=658532.msg4404944#msg4404944 date=1391639135]
Where is this error? You think grabbing the value out of the door by the string position is better,
[/quote]Let alone not having a doors class? You didn’t finish a string literal.

The object click packet sends you three values. Object ID, x ordinate and y ordinate. Your method will lead to you needing to iterate through the array to find the resultant object. Now, incase you didn’t know, a HashMap uses an underlying array. It may not share the same speed but it’s still fast and I think the get function serves me perfectly. I use this to identify the door being clicked. Why do I prefer this way? well I get the position of the object and id from the packet, searching by id will lead to conflicts and thus possibly an irrelevant door being returned and manipulated. So instead I opted to use the position to grab the item.

As for my file parsing, it’s a fairly simplistic approach. For the record, I never said “grabbing the value out of the door by the string position is better”. If you’re referring to how retrieve my Door object, then sure, in my case I think it is.

Explain your side rather than posting two line juvenile comments,

Kind regards,

Pure_[/quote]
I do have a Doors class I just didn’t feel the need to post it here because I was just showing how I load the data. Anyways I’m actually done now you have your way of loading it I have my way of loading it.

King regards,

Dan0194

Read full topic
item.source: I would like working doors for a blank client

item.title: I would like working doors for a blank client
item.dc:creator: @pure2ownage Pure_
item.description:
@pure2ownage wrote:

[quote=“DAn0194, post:16, topic:539690”][quote author=Pure_ link=topic=658532.msg4404939#msg4404939 date=1391638014]

Wow the way you did it is really weird lol. And exactly what I said before I say now why are you using that hashmap when you should be using an array.
[/quote]For the third time, I’m addressing them by position. You cannot search for a string key in an array.

The way you load doors is so weird. Why are you using a string to look it up it doesn’t make sense? anyways I’m done.

Just wanted to show you a better way to load them.

[code=java] /*
* The amount of doors
*/
public static Door[] door = new Door[4];

/**
 * Logger instance.
 */
public static final Logger logger = Logger.getLogger(Door.class.getName());

/*
 * Loads the data from XML and makes a new instance per door
 */
@SuppressWarnings("unchecked")
public static void init() {
	try {
		List<Door> loadedData = (List<Door>) PersistenceManager.load(new FileInputStream("./data/doors.xml"));
			for(int i = 0; i < door.length; i++) {
				door[i] = loadedData.get(i);
				System.out.println(door[i].getX());
			}			
		logger.info("Successfully loaded "+loadedData.size() +" doors.);
	} catch(Exception e) {
		e.printStackTrace();
	}
}[/code][/quote]JESUSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSS CHRISTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTT
  1. Your code has an error in it. Good job pal.
  2. How are you now going to identify what door it is? By looping through your 2,000 doors?
  3. XML is unnecessary file-size due to it being so verboose.
  4. Lol list to array good plan!

My implementation is meant to be lightweight.

Read full topic

item.title: I would like working doors for a blank client
item.dc:creator: @Dan0194 Dan0194
item.description:
@Dan0194 wrote:

[quote=“Pure_, post:15, topic:539690”][quote author=DAn0194 link=topic=658532.msg4404934#msg4404934 date=1391637643]
Wow the way you did it is really weird lol. And exactly what I said before I say now why are you using that hashmap when you should be using an array.
[/quote]For the third time, I’m addressing them by position. You cannot search for a string key in an array.[/quote]
The way you load doors is so weird. Why are you using a string to look it up it doesn’t make sense? anyways I’m done.

Just wanted to show you a better way to load them.

[code=java] /*
* The amount of doors
*/
public static Door[] door = new Door[4];

/**
 * Logger instance.
 */
public static final Logger logger = Logger.getLogger(Door.class.getName());

/*
 * Loads the data from XML and makes a new instance per door
 */
@SuppressWarnings("unchecked")
public static void init() {
	try {
		List<Door> loadedData = (List<Door>) PersistenceManager.load(new FileInputStream("./data/doors.xml"));
			for(int i = 0; i < door.length; i++) {
				door[i] = loadedData.get(i);
				System.out.println(door[i].getX());
			}			
		logger.info("Successfully loaded "+loadedData.size() +" doors.);
	} catch(Exception e) {
		e.printStackTrace();
	}
}[/code]

item.title: I would like working doors for a blank client
item.dc:creator: @pure2ownage Pure_
item.description:
@pure2ownage wrote:

[quote=“DAn0194, post:12, topic:539690”][quote author=Pure_ link=topic=658532.msg4404923#msg4404923 date=1391635254]

[quote author=DAn0194 link=topic=658532.msg4404922#msg4404922 date=1391634965]

[quote author=Pure_ link=topic=658532.msg4404915#msg4404915 date=1391634132]

[quote author=DAn0194 link=topic=658532.msg4404914#msg4404914 date=1391633847]

I told you I’m working on this right now and this post sped up my development (i will release it since i haven’t found any decent ones). I’ve got it working but I don’t think there is a way around storing all the items in a collection of some sort unfortunately - if anybody has suggestions please say so.

Don’t use a collection for doors load it externally or even better from the cache.
[/quote]They are parsed from a file into the collection. As for the cache I know there is an array somewhere containing all game objects. Pretty sure we could use said array to some extent to ease the process.

Hmm why are you using a collection when you can just store it in an array.

[/quote]Uhh… [size=18pt]because I’m using their position as their unique identifier (since object ids, especially in this case are shared)[/size].

That’s not what I meant. When you load your file externally put the data of each door in an array. Like for example.

[/quote]I am not using an array… That aside do you really think I don’t know how to initialize a variable?

ps Do you even know what collections are? Of course I’m loading data into them.

I know what a collection is lol. How are you loading doors externally? Aren’t you doing something like this.

[code=java]
public class Door {

private int doorX;
private int doorY;

public int getX() {
	return doorX;
}

public int getY() {
	return doorY;
}

}[/code]

And then storing different instances of the class to act as each door.

[/quote]You mean how am I storing the parsed data - creating a class like that doesn’t magically load data. Yes I am storing them in a Door file.

I know that… your acting as I’m an idiot, I have loaded stuff externally before. You said your saving each instance in a collection why not an array like I said above.[/quote]I told you that 50 posts ago - check the bold. I’m not acting like you are an idiot, you are what you are.

[hr]

Op here is my first draft, it’s really buggy but logging in and out seems to fix the object syncing. Perhaps try building off that - you aren’t going to get anymore from me. File format is: ID Pos (x y z) Open? (default value) Open face Close face rest not parsed. All split by single tabs.

[code=java]package net.pure2.hades.world;

import java.io.BufferedReader;
import java.io.File;
import java.io.FileReader;
import java.util.HashMap;
import net.pure2.hades.Player;
import net.pure2.hades.entity.Position;
import net.pure2.hades.entity.player.PlayerHandler;
import net.pure2.hades.util.Misc;

/**
*

  • @author Pure_
    */
    public final class DoorHandler {

    // TODO Fix up - sometimes opening/closing spawns doors in weird locations
    // they display well if i relog after doing actions
    // coords seem to be the same as the ones we send
    // - ones after the initial door are messed, maybe the pos region isnt changing?

    /**

    • A collection of our loaded doors, Position toString() against Door.
      */
      private static final HashMap<String, Door> DOORS_LIST = new HashMap<>();

    /**

    • Loads doors from the given file.

    • @param fileName file to load data from
      */
      public static void loadDoors(String fileName) {
      final long startTime = System.currentTimeMillis();

      File file = new File(fileName);

      if (!file.exists()) {
      throw new NullPointerException("Door file does not exist (in "
      + fileName + “)”);
      }

      DOORS_LIST.clear();

      // Loading door data
      try (BufferedReader br = new BufferedReader(new FileReader(file))) {
      String line = null;

       // Reading the file line by line
 while ((line = br.readLine()) != null) {
     // Checking if the line is valid
     if (!line.startsWith("#")) {
         String[] lineComponents = line.split("\t");

         // Door id
         int objId = Integer.parseInt(lineComponents[0]);

         // Position
         String[] positionSeg = lineComponents[1].split(" ");
         int x = Integer.parseInt(positionSeg[0]);
         int y = Integer.parseInt(positionSeg[1]);
         int z = Integer.parseInt(positionSeg[2]);
         Position pos = new Position(x, y, z);
         
         // Default door state
         final boolean defaultState = Boolean.parseBoolean(lineComponents[2]);

         // Door open face
         final int openFace = Misc.getFace(lineComponents[3]);

         // Door closed face
         final int closeFace = Misc.getFace(lineComponents[4]);

         // Adding the door to the doors list
         DOORS_LIST.put(pos.toString(),
                 new Door(objId, pos, defaultState, openFace, closeFace));
     }
 }

      } catch (Exception ex) {
      ex.printStackTrace();
      }

      // Load message
      System.out.println("Loaded " + DOORS_LIST.size() + " doors in “
      + (System.currentTimeMillis() - startTime) + " ms.”);
      }

    /**

    • Flips the state of the door (in the given position).

    • @param pos Position to check
      */
      public static void flipState(Position pos) {
      // Getting the door and flipping its state
      Door door = DOORS_LIST.get(pos.toString());

      if (door == null) {
      return;
      }
      door.flipState();

      // Updating the door for other players
      for (Player p : PlayerHandler.getPlayers()) {
      // Skipping over invalid players
      if (p == null) {
      continue;
      }

       // Sending the object packet
 p.sendObject(door.getObjectId(), door.getObjectType(),
         door.getFace(), door.getPosition());

      }
      }

    /**

    • Sends all door states to the given player.
    • @param player Player
      */
      public static void sendAllDoors(Player player) {
      for (Door door : DOORS_LIST.values()) {
      if (!door.isDefaultState()) {
      player.sendObject(door.getObjectId(), door.getObjectType(),
      door.getFace(), door.getPosition());
      }
      }
      }

    /**

    • Checks if the given coordinates house a valid (handled) door.
    • @param pos Position of
    • @return boolean, door?
      */
      public static boolean isDoor(Position pos) {
      return DOORS_LIST.containsKey(pos.toString());
      }
      }

/**

  • A door object.

  • @author Pure_
    */
    class Door {

    private final int objectId;
    private final Position pos;
    private final int openFace;
    private final int closeFace;
    private final boolean defaultState;
    private boolean open;

    public Door(int objectId, Position pos, boolean defaultState, int openFace, int closeFace) {
    this.objectId = objectId;
    this.pos = pos;
    this.defaultState = defaultState;
    this.open = defaultState;
    this.openFace = openFace;
    this.closeFace = closeFace;
    }

    public void flipState() {
    open = !open;
    }

    public boolean isDefaultState() {
    return open == defaultState;
    }

    public int getObjectId() {
    return objectId;
    }

    public int getObjectType() {
    return 0;
    }

    public int getFace() {
    return open ? openFace : closeFace;
    }

    public Position getPosition() {
    return pos;
    }
    }[/code]

Read full topic

item.title: I would like working doors for a blank client
item.dc:creator: @Dan0194 Dan0194
item.description:
@Dan0194 wrote:

[quote=“Pure_, post:11, topic:539690”][quote author=DAn0194 link=topic=658532.msg4404922#msg4404922 date=1391634965]

[quote author=Pure_ link=topic=658532.msg4404915#msg4404915 date=1391634132]

[quote author=DAn0194 link=topic=658532.msg4404914#msg4404914 date=1391633847]

[quote author=Pure_ link=topic=658532.msg4404913#msg4404913 date=1391633693]

I told you I’m working on this right now and this post sped up my development (i will release it since i haven’t found any decent ones). I’ve got it working but I don’t think there is a way around storing all the items in a collection of some sort unfortunately - if anybody has suggestions please say so.

Don’t use a collection for doors load it externally or even better from the cache.
[/quote]They are parsed from a file into the collection. As for the cache I know there is an array somewhere containing all game objects. Pretty sure we could use said array to some extent to ease the process.

Hmm why are you using a collection when you can just store it in an array.

[/quote]Uhh… because I’m using their position as their unique identifier (since object ids, especially in this case are shared).

That’s not what I meant. When you load your file externally put the data of each door in an array. Like for example.

[/quote]I am not using an array… That aside do you really think I don’t know how to initialize a variable?

ps Do you even know what collections are? Of course I’m loading data into them.

I know what a collection is lol. How are you loading doors externally? Aren’t you doing something like this.

[code=java]
public class Door {

private int doorX;
private int doorY;

public int getX() {
	return doorX;
}

public int getY() {
	return doorY;
}

}[/code]

And then storing different instances of the class to act as each door.

[/quote]You mean how am I storing the parsed data - creating a class like that doesn’t magically load data. Yes I am storing them in a Door file.[/quote]
I know that… your acting as I’m an idiot, I have loaded stuff externally before. You said your saving each instance in a collection why not an array like I said above.

Read full topic

item.title: I would like working doors for a blank client
item.dc:creator: @pure2ownage Pure_
item.description:
@pure2ownage wrote:

[quote=“DAn0194, post:8, topic:539690”][quote author=Pure_ link=topic=658532.msg4404913#msg4404913 date=1391633693]

[quote author=DAn0194 link=topic=658532.msg4404911#msg4404911 date=1391633087]

I told you I’m working on this right now and this post sped up my development (i will release it since i haven’t found any decent ones). I’ve got it working but I don’t think there is a way around storing all the items in a collection of some sort unfortunately - if anybody has suggestions please say so.

Don’t use a collection for doors load it externally or even better from the cache.
[/quote]They are parsed from a file into the collection. As for the cache I know there is an array somewhere containing all game objects. Pretty sure we could use said array to some extent to ease the process.

Hmm why are you using a collection when you can just store it in an array.

[/quote]Uhh… because I’m using their position as their unique identifier (since object ids, especially in this case are shared).

That’s not what I meant. When you load your file externally put the data of each door in an array. Like for example.

private Door[] door = new Door[HOW_MANY_DOORS_ARE_BEING_LOADED][/quote]I am not using an array… That aside do you really think I don’t know how to initialize a variable?

ps Do you even know what collections are? Of course I’m loading data into them.

Read full topic
